Imagine you are playing the game as Ryan.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: David, Ryan, Angela, Shirley, Michelle, Andrew, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Ryan's) goal: Deceive others, avoid detection, and eliminate villagers.

prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as David.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: David, Ryan, Angela, Shirley, Michelle, Andrew, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (David's) goal: Act openly and collaboratively to identify werewolves.

{secret}

Conversation Starts:

Turn #0: [Game] State: Night_werewolf. The game begins!

Turn #1: [Game] Entering state: Night_seer

Turn #2: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #3: [Game] An attack was prevented!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #4: David: said: "It seems that an attack was prevented during the night. This means we still have all our villagers alive, which is a good start. We need to discuss who might be the werewolves among us. I suggest we share any suspicions or observations we've had about each other so far. Who wants to go first?"

Turn #5: Ryan: said: "Glad the kill was stopped—likely the Witch used their save, so we don’t have hard info yet. Seer should stay quiet and keep gathering results. I want to put pressure where it matters: Andrew, give us concrete reads, not hedges; Michelle, who would you vote right now and why? David’s opener is fine. Shirley tends to push proactively as town—interested to hear her take. Early lean from me is Andrew for sitting back so far; if that doesn’t change, I’m comfortable voting there."

Turn #6: Angela: said: "I agree with Ryan that we should keep the pressure on Andrew. I think it's valuable to hear more from him. Andrew, can you explain your thoughts on the current dynamics? Also, I'm curious about what Michelle thinks about David's suggestions."

Turn #7: Shirley: said: "Attack was prevented—likely a Witch save. Power roles should stay quiet. I want concrete stances now. Andrew: give us your top two reads and who you’d vote this minute with reasons. Michelle: same question, and what do you make of Ryan’s push and David’s opener? David, who actually pings you? My leans: slight town on Ryan for driving accountability; David/Angela null. Concern on Andrew for no stance yet; if that doesn’t change I’m fine voting there. If Andrew gives substance, I’ll look to Michelle next if she hedges or won’t commit."

Turn #8: Michelle: said: ""I think it's crucial we focus our efforts on Andrew for now. The lack of concrete stance raises concerns, and both Angela and Ryan have pointed this out. While I appreciate David's opener, it’s our responsibility to hold each other accountable. Personally, I would vote for Andrew if he doesn’t provide clearer insights soon. As for Ryan, I agree with his proactive approach in pushing for clarity from all of us. It’s essential we keep the conversation active, and I’m keen to hear what Andrew has to say. And Shirley, I agree, I could be your next target if I don’t step up with my input.""

Turn #9: Andrew: said: ""I appreciate all the feedback and understand the concerns about my lack of concrete reads. I want to address them directly. First, I believe that Ryan's proactive stance is valid—accountability is crucial. However, I also think we should be cautious about being too hasty to vote someone out without substantial evidence. My current top two reads are: 1) David, who I feel has been approachable and encouraging open discussion, which is a good sign for a Villager; 2) I share some of Angela and Michelle's concerns about Ryan's push; I want to see if it's driven by genuine suspicion or strategic positioning. If I had to vote right now, I'd lean toward Ryan, not because I think he’s a werewolf necessarily, but to encourage more engagement from everyone. I would like to hear specific reasons from each player on who they suspect and why. The more we share, the better we can identify the werewolves together.""

Ryan: [action] vote Andrew

Shirley: [action] vote Andrew
Michelle: [action] vote Andrew
Andrew: [action] vote Ryan
[Game] Andrew was voted out!

Turn #13: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #14: [Game] Angela was killed by werewolves!
[Game] Ryan died by witch's poison!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #15: David: said: ""Wow, two of us were lost last night—Angela to the werewolves and Ryan to the witch's poison. This really narrows down our options and heightens the stakes. I believe we need to closely analyze the votes from the last round and any possible connections. We need to stay strong as villagers. I propose we discuss who voted for Andrew and how they are reacting now. Michelle, you were quick to support the vote—do you still think we were right about him? And Shirley, you've been critical of Andrew; do you have any suspicions about others now? Let's focus on who might be the werewolves among us!""

Turn #16: Shirley: said: "Two dead last night (Angela by wolves, Ryan by witch). Witch likely used both potions already, so this is do-or-die—one wrong elim and we lose. Here’s where I’m at: David is my top suspect. Day 1 he kept it surface-level, then was first to snap-vote Andrew with no real case; today he’s steering the convo and pre-framing Michelle (“you were quick to support the vote”) without committing to a clear suspect himself. That’s classic agenda play—guide consensus, avoid ownership. Michelle’s D1 progression (pressure Andrew, say she’d vote if he stayed vague, then follow through) is at least consistent, not great in hindsight but it tracks and doesn’t feel like manufactured positioning. I’m prepared to vote David unless I get a convincing, specific case otherwise. David: who is your top suspect right now and why, in concrete terms? And why were you first on Andrew yesterday—what exact post convinced you? Michelle: between me and David, who’s more likely the wolf and why? Please commit—no hedging."

Turn #17: Michelle: said: ""I understand the urgency, Shirley, and I appreciate your analysis. Regarding your question, I do think David’s early vote on Andrew seemed hasty, but I also recognize he was trying to keep the game moving. However, I have to agree with you that he might be more suspicious now given the lack of a clear suspect from him today. I’m leaning towards voting David due to this behavior—he’s steering the discussion without committing to a target himself. As for your actions, I think mine have been consistent, but this is a critical moment, and we must choose wisely. I’m prepared to vote for David unless he provides a solid alternative suspect with concrete reasoning. This is do-or-die for us, and I hope we make the right choice.""
